12. The satires oi Juvenal deal largely with social life - at Rome in his own day, and express the leelings of one who had evidently long been familiar with the city. They are worthy ol study, not only as unsurpassed examples oi personal satire, but also lor the vast amount oi informa· tion which they furnish regarding the manners, morals, and belieis of that period. Beyond other ancient writers Juvenal had the power to draw vivid pictures from real lile, sometimes introducing all the details, as in the description ol the distribution ol the sportulam. 9 5-126), more often con- densyng everything into a few lines. It must be admitted ’ that his purpose seems to be rather to condemn the evils of his day than to reform then} Indeed he writes as one who saw no hope of reform. Indignation at the corrupt state of morals drove him to satire (1. 79); disappointment had embittered his feelings, and he naturally exaggerated the evils that he saw around him, and looked at things on their darkest side, but he seems honest in his hatred of sin, and nowhere depicts vice in order to make it alluring.
